captions.text:
You know what I didnít like about Django
Unchained?
What? The 4 or 500 uses of the n-word?

What? No. Wait a minute. Are we gonna hold
this movie about the slave era to our modern

political correctness standards? What were
the white people in the movie supposed to

call black people? Disappointments? Are we
gonna use something innocuous so that we donít
get any historical accuracy in our ears.

Well thereís a difference between historical
accuracy and overkill man. They used that

word, like, three times a sentence in that
movie,
Thatís not an exaggeration at all.

You wanna talk about historical accuracy,
letís talk about Jackie Brown, letís talk
about Pulp Fiction.
Okay, letís talk about ëem.

Those movies are both set in the 90ís and
shot in the 90ís, the single most PC era

thatís ever existed, and the n-wordís all
over both of those movies. I mean, in Pulp

Fiction Tarantino says the word like itís
a stutter. And he says it to Samuel L. Jacksonís
face. That guyís gotta have titanium balls.

I think people are just too sensitive about
words these days.

People are too sensitive about some words
these daysÖ but the n-word, theyíre not

being too sensitive. That word is f*ckiní
toxic, man. Thereís only one word more controversial
than that.
Which is?
(CENSORED)

Dude Ióyou do know this is all on camera
right. Like, I cannot believe you just said
that.

If Tarantino can say the n-word to Samuel
L. Jackson, then why canít I say the naughty
words and flaunt it?

That word isnít naughty, dude, that word
is apocalyptic. Besides, Iím sure that Sam
Jackson had a conversation with--

Yeah, ìSamî Jackson, like heís youíre
buddy.

Okay, Samuel L. Motherf*cking Jackson. The
point is, do you think he would have done
the movie if he was offended?
He certainly wasnít offended by the paycheck.

Dude, everybody worked for scale on that movie.
It was made for 8 million dollars and half
of that probably went to the gimp.

Oh, a gimp doesnít cost anything. Come on.
I can have a gimp here by 5 PM, with accessories.

The point is, about Django Unchained I didnít
like the scene where they were taking Django
to the mine.
What was wrong with that?

Well, everything. It feels tacked on, Tarantino
indulges his acting bug again playing an Australian

slave driver. The sceneís only there, so
it can pay off the horrible things Django
did.
Django was the hero...

Was he? Was he really? Let's remember heís
coming back to save his wife.
That's a noble thing...

Yeah, itís noble. But think about what he
has to do to save his wife. He transforms

into this method actor, becoming a black bounty
hunter so vile he makes Uncle Tom look like
Snow White.
Yeah, he had to convince Leonardo DiCaprio.

Right, but then even after he had convinced
DiCaprio and everybody else, he still lets

that other black guy get lynched, without
stopping it, even though Christoph Waltz is

there and offers to pay good money to save
the guy. And the only way that pays off is

if there's something that happens in the story
later on where he can then be vouched for

by slaves who can say, you know, heís not
with us, or heís not one of us.
The scene where he's being led to the mines...

Yes. You just allowed all this suffering and
let a man die a horrible death just in the

event you were being led away into a remote
mineÖ just in the event other slaves were

with you that could vouch for your storyÖ
and just in the event the white people believe

your story and let you goÖ then maybe it
would pay off and you could go see your wife

again. I say in the end, Django was the thing
he was pretending to be.

I say Iíd like to see you say that to a group
of black people.
I donít really know any black people.
Thatís racist.
You donít really know any black people either.

Yeah, but I don't go around telling everybody
about it.

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - Django Unchained

comments.author: 20killershot

comments.text:
+The Hermit Man  Yes, of course, gross generalization. But look, I 
understand, the effectiveness of words are based on our interpretation and 
usage, Nigger has been a derogatory word as far as I know and it still is, 
Thank all knowing Vsauce but the word awful was never used to point out an 
exclusive race.
comments.author: Oluseyi Adekola

comments.text:
+Oluseyi Adekola There is no wrong for one, right for another when it comes 
to use of language.  If I hear you use a word you best shut your mouth when 
I say it back.  There are no wrong words, only our PC interpretation of 
such words.  I am sure not everyone knows the origin of nigger because that 
is a gross generalization.  Vsauce makes a great video about words and how 
our interpretation changes in less than 50 years for some of them.  Awful 
is the example I remember.  Most people see it as "that's terrible" but it 
used to mean something was full of awe or awesome to behold.
comments.author: The Hermit Man

comments.text:
+The Hermit Man Look I'm not saying  the word is wrong, I'm saying black 
people are wrong, we all know the origin and use of the word "nigger", and 
if u don't you're a fucking asshole. My problem is with black folk deciding 
to call each other "nigga" and saying since its a variation it means 
something else. its OK for them to use it but wrong for white people, i 
just wish they had been smart enough to eradicate that word from their 
vocab. Shit would have been so much different.
comments.author: Oluseyi Adekola

comments.text:
+Oluseyi Adekola Words are not wrong.  Variation of words are not 
wrong.  People worrying over a certain word being spoken or written is 
wrong though.
comments.author: The Hermit Man

What a fuckin idiot. U need to shut the fuck up . Black people are wrong

comments.author: dusty fairview

comments.text:
It kind of bothers me that he tries to get audience points by claiming that 
"no one is being sensitive about the word 'nigger'. That word is toxic"... 
But, considering it is just a word and the potential reaction it could 
insight, i think it's pretty clear that people ARE being a bit too 
sensitive about it. Also, i live in Baltimore city, in an area where white 
people are the minority. And, after hearing the word 'nigger' used like 
punctuation, it was pretty much unavoidable that i would start using it the 
same way, and i can only recall exactly TWO times (out of literally 
HUNDREDS) that i was told it offended someone, i started i didn't mean to 
offend, and it was done. And both times, they were Muslim. So this over the 
top reaction that word supposedly insights is just a media exaggeration﻿

comments.author: Oakenshield263

comments.text:
You're totally right, I know where your coming from being from East 
Cleveland, there you hear 9 and 10 year olds saying it. No matter how many 
times people say its wrong or shouldn't be said, people will still say it. 
I'm probably gonna get at least some hate for saying this but it's the same 
thing with the word retard, anyone who doesn't know what retardation is, 
look it up before bitching at me. People with mental disabilities are by 
definition mentally retarded, but when people started using it as an 
offense to the quote "normal people" it became taboo and bad. But now with 
the word nigger it is in the past that it was used in a derogatory way, but 
now most people don't use it as such and we still say its wrong. They are 
doing nothing wrong and generally mean no offense by it, sometimes using it 
to call you friend etc. People hear it and only think its bad because of 
the past. Acknowledging what you said in terms of media exaggeration is 
also true, they see or hear a murderer say it, or a rapist, someone who did 
something bad or illegal say it and they jump on top of it and give the 
word even more bad publicity. Things are only offensive if you take them as 
offensive.

comments.text:
+misterfukin
"he didnt give a fuck about his kin" - possible, but the scene does not 
show that. There is nothing Django can do for that slave in that moment; he 
would just get killed if he did anything. Also, it is very unlikely that 
Tarantino tried to show Django's callousness in this scene. The movie isn't 
that deep.
comments.author: BartJ583

comments.text:
+BartJ583 its a scene which proves, violently, the non existing value for 
the slaves these persons had, especially with django. he was the focus, he 
didnt give a fuck about his kin, or about anyone. django wasnt a slave 
anymore or had any sense of revenge branded by skin or color, he never 
wanted revenge, he just wanted his girl at that point
comments.author: misterfukin

comments.text:
They are giving the movie way too much credit. That scene isn't in the 
movie to set up the other scene at the mine; nor is it in there to prove 
that Candy is a sick bastard - that is already well established by the time 
of this scene.
No. This scene is in the movie for shock value. Simple, cheap, lame shock 
value.

+RaptorNX01 Another reason oriental is offensive is because it presumes

comments.author: RectPropagation

comments.text:
I dunno, was the word even thought of as being as vile then as it is today? 
We like to put our modern sensibilities on things in the past, but 
perceptions change. As does the emotional impact of certain words. Consider 
Oriental, it's only in recent years that the word has been considered 
"offensive". and most of that has to do with the people's of the various 
nations being bitter over the idea of being lumped in with people from 
countries they dislike.

comments.text:

don't remember anything that would indicate he wasn't a slaver, although I 
guess they saw him being so desperate and figure it our. Still I'm not

didn't work for me. It was to conviniant for me.
comments.author: MadBunnyRabbit

comments.text:
+RaptorNX01 I know what he's trying to say and I totally disagree. People, 
at that time at least, did not buy slaves to drink tea and chat with. They 
bought them and made them work on fields, for god knows how many hours 
without rest or food, or in mines, railroads etc. Too many of them died 
during work, under TERRIBLE conditions and most of them died of hunger. 
Blacks at that time were a mere commodity, expendable tools not just 
house-hold servants like you think.
comments.author: Johan Bach

comments.text:
+Johan Bach
He's talking about the whole, constantly whipping them, torturing them, etc 
etc stuff. That it was mainly treating them as indentured servants rather 
then slaves. (mind we are talking about the slave owners, not the slavers 
though. different ball of wax)

+MadBunnyRabbit My take on it was that they knew he wasn't a slaver. though 
i agree that whole bit was awkwardly edited.
